news_summary: New discoveries reveal that early humans were butchering elephants as far back as 1.8 million years ago, shedding light on ancient human behavior and adaptation.

articles.title: Early humans may have begun butchering elephants 1.8 million years ago
articles.summary: A 1.78-million-year-old partial elephant skeleton found in Tanzania associated with stone tools may represent the oldest known evidence of butchery of the giant herbivores
articles.content:
A 1.78-million-year-old partial elephant skeleton found in Tanzania associated with stone tools may represent the oldest known evidence of butchery of the giant herbivores

Ancient humans taking on an elephant – our ancestors may have begun butchering the animals 1.8 million years ago NATURAL HISTORY MUSEUM, LONDON/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY

Butchering an elephant is an extraordinarily difficult feat, requiring serious tools and cooperation, with the reward being a protein bonanza.

Now a team of researchers led by Manuel Domínguez-Rodrigo at Rice University in Texas say that ancient humans may have achieved this milestone 1.78 million years ago at Olduvai Gorge in Tanzania.

“At about 2 million years ago humans were systematically consuming animals like gazelles or waterbucks, but not bigger game,” says Domínguez-Rodrigo.

A little later, evidence from Olduvai Gorge hints that things changed. The gorge is rich in animal and hominin fossils that formed between about 2 million and 17,000 years ago, and at approximately 1.8 million years ago there is a sudden change in the type of animal bones preserved, with remains of elephants and hippos becoming much more abundant. Even so, proving they had been butchered by humans remained difficult, he says.

Then, in June 2022, Domínguez-Rodrigo and his colleagues discovered what appears to be an ancient elephant butchery site at Olduvai.

The site, which they named the EAK site, consisted of the partial skeleton of an extinct elephant species called Elephas recki, surrounded by large numbers of stone tools of a type much larger and more heavy-duty than the stone tools that had been used by hominins before the 2 million year mark. These new tools, says Domínguez-Rodrigo, were likely manufactured by an ancient human called Homo erectus.

“They include Pleistocene knives that are as sharp when we excavated them as they were when [ancient] humans used them.”

Domínguez-Rodrigo and his colleagues think that the stone tools were used to butcher the elephant. Some of the large limb bones seem to have been broken shortly after the elephant’s death, while the bones were still fresh – or “green”. Scavengers like hyenas could have torn flesh from the carcasses, but they are unable to break the shafts of adult or almost adult elephant bones, he says.

“We documented a couple of such bones in our site bearing green fractures, thereby showing that humans had broken them using hammerstones,” he says. “These green broken bones are abundant across the landscape sampled 1.7 million years ago and also bear frequently percussion marks associated with them.”

There is, however, little evidence of the scratches – or cut marks – that butchery can sometimes leave on bones when meat is removed.

What is not known is whether humans killed the elephant or just stumbled across the carcass and opportunistically took advantage of it.

“The only secure thing that we can say is that they butchered it, or part of it, and in the process left a few tools with its bones,” says Domínguez-Rodrigo.

He adds that the transition to butchering elephants was not simply due to the invention of better stone tools but also a sign that hominin groups were beginning to grow larger, resulting in social and cultural changes.

But Michael Pante at Colorado State University is not convinced by the research.

The evidence that this individual elephant was exploited by human ancestors is weak, says Pante. This is because the interpretation relies on the stone tools and the elephant bones being close together and the presence of fractures interpreted to have been made by human ancestors seeking marrow, says Pante.

Pante argues that the earliest definitive evidence for butchery of hippos, giraffes and elephants at Olduvai Gorge comes 80,000 years later at a 1.7-million-year-old site he and his colleagues analysed, named HWK EE.

“Unlike the EAK site the bones of these taxa [at the HWK EE site] have cut marks and are in association with thousands of other bones and artifacts in archaeological context,” he says.
articles.reasoning: The discovery of the oldest known evidence of elephant butchery by early humans 1.78 million years ago represents a significant scientific breakthrough in understanding human evolution, social behavior, and technological advancement. It has broad significance for anthropology and human history, providing tangible insights into early human cooperation and tool use. The article focuses on this single important archaeological finding with sufficient detail and context, despite some scholarly debate.
articles.personality_title: Ancient humans butchered elephants nearly 1.8 million years ago, new discovery shows
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Around 2 million years ago, early humans hunted smaller animals like gazelles but had not yet tackled large animals such as elephants. Olduvai Gorge in Tanzania is a famous archaeological site where many ancient animal and human fossils have been found, dating back millions of years.

**What happened** – In June 2022, researchers led by Manuel Domínguez-Rodrigo found a partial skeleton of an extinct elephant species, Elephas recki, at Olduvai Gorge. Around this skeleton, they discovered large stone tools likely made by Homo erectus, an early human species. The bones showed signs of being broken while still fresh, suggesting humans used the tools to butcher the elephant.

**Impact** – This finding could be the oldest known evidence that humans butchered elephants, showing that early humans had developed stronger tools and likely worked together to take on large animals. Breaking elephant bones to access marrow is very difficult, so the discovery reveals new details about the social and technological skills of our ancestors nearly 1.8 million years ago.

**What's next step** – Scientists will continue to study this site and others to better understand how and when early humans started hunting or scavenging large animals. There is still debate about whether the humans killed the elephant or only took advantage of its carcass, so more evidence will help clarify these behaviors.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Stone tools and broken elephant bones found in Tanzania suggest early humans butchered large animals nearly 1.8 million years ago, highlighting advances in tool use and social cooperation.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les premiers humains ont peut-être découpé des éléphants il y a près de 1,8 million d’années, selon une nouvelle découverte
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Il y a environ 2 millions d’années, les premiers humains chassaient de petits animaux comme les gazelles, mais pas encore les gros animaux comme les éléphants. La gorge d’Olduvai en Tanzanie est un site archéologique célèbre où de nombreux fossiles d’animaux et d’humains anciens ont été découverts, datant de millions d’années.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En juin 2022, des chercheurs dirigés par Manuel Domínguez-Rodrigo ont trouvé un squelette partiel d’une espèce d’éléphant éteinte, Elephas recki, à la gorge d’Olduvai. Autour de ce squelette, ils ont découvert de gros outils en pierre probablement fabriqués par Homo erectus, une espèce humaine ancienne. Les os montraient des signes d’avoir été cassés alors qu’ils étaient encore frais, ce qui suggère que les humains ont utilisé ces outils pour découper l’éléphant.

**Impact** – Cette découverte pourrait être la plus ancienne preuve connue que les humains découpaient des éléphants, montrant que nos ancêtres avaient développé des outils plus solides et travaillaient probablement ensemble pour s’attaquer à de gros animaux. Casser les os d’éléphants pour accéder à la moelle est très difficile, donc cette découverte apporte de nouveaux détails sur les compétences sociales et technologiques de nos ancêtres il y a près de 1,8 million d’années.

**Étape suivante** – Les scientifiques continueront d’étudier ce site et d’autres pour mieux comprendre comment et quand les premiers humains ont commencé à chasser ou à exploiter les gros animaux. Il y a encore un débat pour savoir si les humains ont tué l’éléphant ou seulement profité de sa carcasse, donc plus de preuves aideront à clarifier ces comportements.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Des outils en pierre et des os d’éléphant cassés trouvés en Tanzanie suggèrent que les premiers humains découpaient de gros animaux il y a près de 1,8 million d’années, montrant des progrès dans l’utilisation des outils et la coopération sociale.
articles.personality_title_es: Los primeros humanos pudieron desmembrar elefantes hace casi 1,8 millones de años, muestra nuevo hallazgo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Hace unos 2 millones de años, los primeros humanos cazaban animales pequeños como gacelas, pero no animales grandes como elefantes. La Garganta de Olduvai en Tanzania es un sitio arqueológico famoso donde se han encontrado muchos fósiles antiguos de animales y humanos que datan de millones de años.

**Qué pasó** – En junio de 2022, investigadores dirigidos por Manuel Domínguez-Rodrigo encontraron un esqueleto parcial de una especie extinta de elefante llamada Elephas recki en la Garganta de Olduvai. Alrededor del esqueleto hallaron grandes herramientas de piedra probablemente hechas por Homo erectus, una especie humana antigua. Los huesos mostraban señales de haberse roto cuando todavía estaban frescos, lo que sugiere que los humanos usaron las herramientas para desmembrar al elefante.

**Impacto** – Este hallazgo podría ser la evidencia más antigua conocida de que los humanos desmembraban elefantes, mostrando que nuestros antepasados desarrollaron herramientas más fuertes y probablemente trabajaban juntos para enfrentarse a animales grandes. Romper huesos de elefante para sacar la médula es muy difícil, por lo que el descubrimiento revela nuevas habilidades sociales y tecnológicas de nuestros antepasados hace casi 1,8 millones de años.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos seguirán estudiando este y otros sitios para entender mejor cómo y cuándo los primeros humanos empezaron a cazar o aprovechar animales grandes. Aún se debate si los humanos mataron al elefante o solo aprovecharon su cadáver, por lo que se necesita más evidencia para aclarar estas conductas.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Herramientas de piedra y huesos de elefante rotos encontrados en Tanzania sugieren que los primeros humanos desmembraban animales grandes hace casi 1,8 millones de años, mostrando avances en el uso de herramientas y la cooperación social.
